stem: The nurse is assessing clients with heart failure. For each finding, select whether it is primarily a consequence of Left-Sided Heart Failure or Right-Sided Heart Failure. Each finding may indicate more than one condition.

rows.text: Jugular venous distension (JVD) and peripheral edema.
Audible crackles (rales) in the lung bases.

rationale.correct:
Heart failure occurs when the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs. The side affected dictates the primary symptoms. 

(r1) Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND) and orthopnea are classic signs of left-sided heart failure.  When lying down, fluid redistributes from the extremities to the lungs, exacerbating pulmonary congestion. This increased fluid in the lungs causes shortness of breath, especially at night (PND) or when lying flat (orthopnea).

(r2) Jugular venous distension (JVD) and peripheral edema are hallmarks of right-sided heart failure. Right-sided failure causes blood to back up into the systemic venous circulation, leading to increased pressure in the jugular veins (JVD) and fluid accumulation in the tissues (peripheral edema).

(r3) Ascites (fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity) and hepatomegaly (enlarged liver) are also indicative of right-sided heart failure.  The increased venous pressure from right-sided failure causes fluid to leak into the peritoneal space (ascites) and congestion of the liver (hepatomegaly).

(r4) Audible crackles (rales) in the lung bases are a key finding in left-sided heart failure.  The backup of blood into the pulmonary circulation causes fluid to leak into the alveoli, producing the characteristic crackling sound upon auscultation.

(r5) Fatigue and decreased cardiac output are systemic consequences common to both left- and right-sided heart failure, though often originating from left-sided dysfunction. The heart's inability to pump effectively reduces oxygen delivery to the tissues, leading to fatigue.
rationale.incorrect: Isolated right-sided heart failure (cor pulmonale) primarily affects the systemic circulation and does not typically cause pulmonary edema or crackles unless there is concurrent left heart involvement.  Left-sided heart failure primarily affects the pulmonary circulation.
clinicalPearls: The most common cause of right-sided heart failure is chronic left-sided heart failure. Treating the underlying left-sided heart failure often improves right-sided symptoms.
Monitor daily weights and intake/output to assess fluid balance in heart failure patients.
Elevate the head of the bed to reduce preload and improve breathing in patients with heart failure.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'L' for Lungs (Left failure) and 'R' for Rest-of-body (Right failure). However, remember that both sides can contribute to fatigue.

reviewUnits.heading: Heart Failure Pathophysiology
reviewUnits.body: Left-sided heart failure involves systolic or diastolic dysfunction of the left ventricle, leading to decreased cardiac output and pulmonary congestion. Right-sided heart failure often results from pulmonary hypertension or left heart disease, causing systemic venous congestion. Key nursing goals: Preload and afterload reduction, improving contractility.
